Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: SensorFly: Minimalistic Dynamic Sensing and Organization in Groups of Semi-Controllable Mobile Sensing Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In a rapidly developing emergency situation the timely discovery of discovery of information about the inside of a building, such as temperature during a fire, is key to a successful response. A challenge is that the needed sensors are difficult to deploy and maintain in these situations. While robots can be used to gather some information, considerations of deployment logistics, dynamic environment, infrastructural dependence, reliability, and speed have limited their adoption. To address these problems, this project explores a novel approach of using a collection of simple controlled mobile air vehicles with sensors (SensorFly). By taking a minimalistic approach, where each device has few sensors, the SensorFly project will develop a basic understanding of such controlled-mobile networked systems, including trade-offs between per device capability and system capability, and low-level collaborative techniques to counter system non-determinism. To test models and evaluate different approaches, the project builds on testbeds involving SensorFly nodes, a low-cost 30-gram flying sensor node.

The SensorFly project has the potential for broad social impact. Studies that improve information gathering in emergency situations will improve safety for both the responders and building occupants. Although the size and weight of available sensors and platforms may decrease over time, the application of minimal mobile sensing platforms will remain attractive due to their reduced intrusiveness. Therefore, the investigation into minimalistic approaches will have a lasting impact that extends beyond today's sensing systems. Finally, the project continues the PI's efforts for advising students in research and encouraging members of under-represented groups into science and engineering fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a rapidly developing emergency situation, such as during emergency response (fire monitoring, clearing a building, etc.), the rapid discovery of intelligence inside a building is key to the success of the response. To assist the efforts of the responders in these dangerous and potentially life-threatening situations, traditional sensor networks and robotic solutions have difficulty due to the difficulty of deployment, reliability, and speed. This work shows a paradigm shift in the approach to the problem by taking a minimalistic semi-controlled mobile sensor network approach in the form of micro-UAV swarms. A system such as this is much less deterministic than traditional approaches but trades off the sensing capability with dramatically improved system coverage and speed. We have developed the

SensorFly platform, a ~30g miniature helicopter-based sensing node. While the weight improves the nodes’ resilience, it also limits sensing capabilities. Thus, our work utilizes these limited capabilities and allow multiple drones to work together to understand the environment.

This work focused on 1) understand the tradeoff between per-device sensing with collaborative system capability in the navigation of the drones in a building, 2) allowing the drone group to understand the environment, and 3) created tools so similar research can be vastly sped up. The work modeled many of these parameters using a probabilistic model, allowing the system to be deployable in many scenarios and self-adapt as the system operates. 

 

The project resulted in many publications, workshops that will help other researchers. It funded Ph.D. students to work in this area and eventually push the state of the art forward. Currently, several universities are using the SensorFly system for both current research and project courses. Parts of the project was done as summer research opportunities to encourage underrepresented citizens to enter research. For generating broad interest and outreach to the general public, our work has been featured in media outlets (CBS, Science Channel Michio Kaku’s Science of the Impossible), as well as popular magazines (New Scientist, Popular Science, BBC Focus etc.). Furthermore, to ensure applicability of our work, we worked with the Roseville Police Department to understand realistic and fundamental requirements of potential users of these systems. Most of all, it will produce future systems that can significantly reduce the risk to fire-fighters and police in dangerous situations.
